name: Data Protection & Secrets Management
description: Your Journal API stores user entries, connects to a database, and talks to an LLM provider—all of which involve sensitive data. If someone gets access to your database password or API key, they can do serious damage. In this topic, we'll cover how encryption protects your data and how secrets management keeps your credentials out of your code.

learning_steps.description: Let's start with how encryption actually works. You don't need to become a cryptographer, but you should understand the difference between encrypting data that's sitting in a database vs. data that's moving over the network.

learning_steps.title: Data Protection in the Cloud

learning_steps.description: The OWASP API Security Top 10 is especially relevant—your Journal API is an API, so these are exactly the risks you need to watch for.

This protects data sitting in your database or storage bucket. Think about your Journal API's database—if someone got access to the raw database files, encryption at rest means they'd just see gibberish.

- Uses symmetric encryption (same key encrypts and decrypts)
- Most cloud databases enable this by default, but you should verify it
- Your PostgreSQL data from the Journal API should absolutely have this turned on

This protects data as it moves between systems—like when your Journal API talks to the database, or when a user's browser sends a request to your API.

- Uses TLS/SSL (that's what the 'S' in HTTPS stands for)
- Your API should only accept HTTPS connections
- Database connections should use TLS too—no plaintext passwords flying over the network

Encryption is only as strong as how you manage your keys. If someone gets your encryption key, the encryption is useless.

- **Provider-managed keys**: The cloud provider handles everything—simpler but less control
- **Customer-managed keys**: You control key rotation and access policies—more work, more control
- **Key rotation**: Regularly changing keys limits exposure if one is compromised. Cloud services can automate this for you.

For your Journal API, provider-managed keys are a great starting point.
learning_steps.title: Key Management

learning_steps.description:
Remember that `.env` file from Phase 3 with your database password and LLM API key? That works for local dev, but in production you need something better. Secrets management services let you:

- Store credentials outside your code (no more hardcoded passwords!)
- Rotate secrets automatically
- Track who accessed what secret and when
- Control which services can read which secrets

Think about what secrets your Journal API uses: database connection string, LLM API key, maybe a JWT signing key. All of these should live in a secrets manager in production.

Not all data needs the same level of protection. Understanding this helps you focus your efforts where they matter most:

- **Public**: Marketing pages, docs—no risk if exposed
- **Internal**: Internal notes—low risk
- **Confidential**: Your Journal API user entries—moderate risk, needs encryption
- **Restricted**: Payment info, passwords, API keys—high risk, needs maximum protection

Your Journal API's user entries are at least Confidential. Database credentials are Restricted.
Pick the one for your cloud provider and read through the getting started guide. You'll use one of these in the capstone to replace your `.env` file approach.
If you want to really understand how encryption works under the hood, these are fun interactive challenges. CryptoHack is especially well-made.
